text: sweaty sweaty no ear the Internet's
busiest music nerd and it's time for a
review of the new sunny day in Glasgow
record sea when absent you know these
days there's a lot of boring shoegaze
and dream pop out there underground
bands that are carelessly churning out
needlessly boring songs that do nothing
but hide behind the most lazily
generated wall of distortion or reverb
these walls of sound are not really
living up to the mastery of groups like
My Bloody Valentine and slow dive and
Cocteau twins Galaxie 500 there are some
newer groups who I happen to love as
well like beach house and the radio
department but these other new groups
that I don't really care for I feel like
they're not really smearing their songs
and beautiful mind-expanding studio
trickery like a lot of these greats do
instead they're just trying to obscure a
lack of interesting song ideas a sunny
day in Glasgow though I've never
considered them to be one of these
groups but I have been a little on the
fence with them over the years the
band's name itself seems to kind of
stand in the shadow of the heritage of
the music they pull from so strongly
noise pop and twee pop and shoegaze and
their first couple of records even
though they are rife with sonic
experiments they're a little too
disjointed and hairbrained to really
catch on beyond a few singles or tracks
that were hot on the blogosphere in the
early days of the music blogosphere and
like the late 2000s however in 2010 the
band dropped a record that totally went
through my radar and it just so happened
to be maybe their most concise and
accessible record yet and this newer
record of theirs to me kind of goes back
to the raw experimentation of their
debut of their sophomore record but also
incorporates these more straightforward
pop appeals this record is catchy
this record is sweet and yet it is also
wildly psychedelic adventurous and kind
of dense there are some tracks on this
LP that do come off pretty
straightforward though songs like
crushing a lazy little love ballad of a
song with booming drums and watery
guitars and synthesizers the
simultaneously heavy but light airy and
fluffy and the song the body bends has
some of the most intelligible vocals on
the entire record really raw upfront
strong bold confident delivery in the
singing I love it and the blissful
explosion of guitars on the chorus of
this track makes for one of the most
beautiful moments on this album and a
sunny day in Glasgow still manages to
sound sweet as they deliver some of the
weirdest sonic experiments I've heard on
a pop record this year like the very
warm but suffocating distortion on the
song bye-bye big ocean which features
all these off-kilter drum beats and
bouncy echo a lead vocals swimming
through this sea of distortion or the
really weird shouting on the refrain of
the song in love with useless which
every time this voice shouts there's the
screaming pitch echoing from behind it
but as soon as the voice stops the noise
stops it's like the voice is coming from
Pandora's box and in order to hear every
word you need to open and close the box
each time simultaneously letting out the
lead vocal and screams from hell and
there is a killer pop song underneath
all of the psychedelic mess of this song
I also have the blissful buzzing guitar
solos on the back end of this track this
song just melts beautifully all the
sounds together this record in general
is really just a beautiful melt of
sounds there's oh I'm a record which has
some of the weirdest vocal edits on the
entire album or golden wave which sounds
like something panda bear would have
co-produced with Grimes but they didn't
really get along that well so they were
frustrated the whole time and they were
trying to get through real fast I sort
of mean that in an interesting way but
the really weird attention-grabbing
chipmunk vocals hanging in the
background of this track are kind of
obnoxious and that's the thing with some
of these tracks and some of these
experiments they do sort of tend to
overstay their welcome here and there
mostly if there's not really that great
of a song hanging in the background like
the things they do to me or the song
never nothing which is an incredibly
drab to
and are really uneventful instrumental
to back it up but a lot of these songs
feeling long isn't necessarily a bad
thing I feel like a sunny day in Glasgow
really goes the mile with some of these
tracks these could have simply been one
two or three minute songs but a lot of
the time these guys are stretching these
tracks out to four or five minutes which
in the grand scheme of popular music
isn't that long but there's just
something about these tracks that just
makes them feel longer than they
actually are it's like yeah they're
poppy they're catchy but they also feel
like a bit of a drone a soundscape but
I'm listening to some of these tracks
some of the best tracks on this LP time
kind of stops or slows down a little bit
which i think is a pretty intriguing
effect for any album to have really for
the most part I do like this album I
think it's a really great noise pop
shoegaze record I think it's one of the
most creative in terms of sonic
experimentation in a while barring the
new My Bloody Valentine record with some
of these songs being as long and as
multifaceted as they are not all of the
various parts of these tracks mesh
together really well especially on some
of the songs that have intended
sloppiness in the instrumentation that
kind of leaves a sour taste in my ears
but on the whole I think the band pulled
together a really creative interesting
sweet fun colorful tracks that I can
really dive into the sound play of I'm
feeling a strong 7 to a light 8 on this
thing transition if you've given this
thing a listen what did you think of it
did you love it did you hate it why what
do you think I should review next and
that's what sunny day in Glasgow forever
